H0.text: Colony is the type of social structure that ants, termites, bees, and wasps live in, which may include millions of individual insects.

H1.text: Family is the type of social structure that may include millions of individual insects in which ants, termites, bees, and wasps live.

H2.text: Habitat is the type of social structure in which ants, termites, bees, and wasps live, and it may include millions of individual insects.

H3.text: Community is the type of social structure in which ants, termites, bees, and wasps live, potentially including millions of individual insects.

A4.text: The order Hymenoptera contains the largest group of eusocial insects, including ants, bees, and waspsâ€”divided into castes: reproductive queens, drones, more or less sterile workers, and sometimes also soldiers that perform specialized tasks.

A5.text: Eusocial colonies can be viewed as superorganisms, with individual castes being analogous to different tissue or cell types in a multicellular organism; castes fulfill a specific role that contributes to the functioning and survival of the whole colony, while being incapable of independent survival outside the colony.
